title: 107_hr476
content: The "Child Custody Protection Act" may be cited as the short title. Title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new chapter on the transportation of minors in circumvention of certain laws relating to abortion. The "Child Custody Protection Act" establishes penalties for knowingly transporting a minor across state lines to obtain an abortion, in violation of parental involvement laws. Offenders may face fines or imprisonment for up to one year. The "Child Custody Protection Act" prohibits transporting a minor across state lines for an abortion without parental consent or judicial authorization, except in cases where the minor's life is at risk due to a physical disorder or illness. Transporters and parents of the minor cannot be prosecuted for violating this law. The "Child Custody Protection Act" prohibits transporting a minor across state lines for an abortion without parental consent or judicial authorization. An affirmative defense is available if the defendant reasonably believed that the necessary consent or notification had been obtained. Parents can seek relief in a civil action for violations of the law. The "Child Custody Protection Act" defines parental involvement in a minor's abortion decision as requiring parental notification or consent before the procedure. The term 'parent' includes a parent, guardian, legal custodian, or a person standing in loco parentis. The "Child Custody Protection Act" defines parental involvement in a minor's abortion decision as requiring notification or consent from a designated person. The term 'minor' refers to an individual not older than the maximum age specified in the law. The definition of 'State' includes the District of Columbia and other territories of the United States. The "Child Custody Protection Act" amends Title 18, United States Code, by adding a new item after chapter 117. The "Child Custody Protection Act" adds a new item after chapter 117, titled "Transportation of minors in circumvention of certain laws relating to abortion." Passed by the House of Representatives on April 17, 2002.
